Région Afrique – Projet de

            environnementale : Résumé

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - West Africa Capital Markets
            Project : environmental assessment

authors.authr:
Buursink International Consultants in
            Environmental Management

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of the West Africa Capital
            Markets Project is to foster the development of unified
            financial markets to attain a sustainable regional
            integration, through strengthened institutional capacities,
            able to manage the sub-region's economies, and
            activities associated with the development of capital
            markets. To this end, one of its components supports the
            development of a strategy towards an integrated transport
            sector, backed by the Roads Sector Environmental and Social
            Management Framework Study, which assesses global
            environmental, and social conditions as related to road
            construction. This environmental management plan (EMP)
            reviews the study, and accordingly, identifies mitigation
            measures, applicable to the West Africa countries - Benin,
            Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Guinea Bissau, Mali,
            Niger, Senegal, and Togo - to minimize environmental
            adversity as a result of road construction. Mainly, this EMP
            endorses the Framework Study recommendations, and
            incorporates measures as follows. The West African
            Development Bank will establish environmental and social
            guidelines, provide technical assistance (TA), and ensure
            mechanisms to enforce environmental protection regulations.
            Specifically, regarding the roads sector, and following
            public awareness campaigns, member states should adopt
            directives for inclusion of precautionary clauses in road
            construction contracts that include water and soil pollution
            control, noise abatement, waste management control, and
            traffic safety measures. Additionally, environmental
            training should be provided to transport service personnel,
            executing agencies staff, and nongovernmental organizations,
            including on environmental monitoring, and the conduct of
            internal and mid-term evaluation of road construction practices.
